ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
ETHNIC INTEGRATION POLICY


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Zainudin Nordin -

    1. To ask the Minister for National development (a) how effective is the Ethnic Integration Policy; (b) how many appeals have been received by the Housing and Development Board for waiver of the policy on the grounds of (i) sales due to divorce, (ii) acquisition of new flats and (iii) financial difficulties; (c) how many of such appeals have been successful; (d) whether there has been an increase of such appeals; (e) what is the assistance that HDB renders to these cases; and (f) whether there will be a further review or refinement of the policy in the near future.

    Mr Loh Meng See (Jalan Besar): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the

Column: 2859

Ethnic Integration Policy (EIP) was implemented in 1989 to promote racial harmony in public housing estates. The policy maintains the proportion of each ethnic group within certain neighbourhood and block limits.

    The EIP has improved the ethnic balance in HDB estates. In 1989, 28% out of the 125 neighbourhoods had at least one ethnic group which reached or exceeded the neighbourhood limit. Now, there are 25% of such neighbourhoods, although the number of neighbourhoods has grown from 125 to 165.

    Between January and July this year, HDB received 181 appeals for waiver of EIP for resale of flat. The flat sellers appealed for waiver of EIP to widen their base of potential buyers in order to secure higher selling prices for their flats.

    Most of them were selling their flats to buy another HDB flat or private property while some indicated financial difficulty as the reason for the sale. Only 7% appealed to waive the EIP for resale of their flat due to divorce.

    As the EIP is very important in maintaining racial harmony in Singapore, we have to apply it consistently. Waiver is granted on a very exceptional basis.

    The EIP has worked well in forging ethnic integration and harmony among HDB residents. We will regularly review and refine the policy if necessary.

Column: 2859

RETUNING THE CPF


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on the Prime Minister's Statement [28th August, 2003].

    Question again proposed.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to join in this discussion.

    I have a few points to make on the recent announcements on the CPF and I hope I will not repeat too many points here.

Column: 2860



    Firstly, I am of the opinion that the cut is not deep enough if we are really trying to meet our objective as spelt out in the Prime Minister's speech and that of the NTUC's chief, Mr Lim Boon Heng. If our reason is to make our workforce a more competitive lot from a wages' point of view, then I personally think that the cut could be deeper. A three percentage point cut can save employers about $1.3 billion a year. The bulk of this saving will be appreciated by the biggest employer, the Government and the Government-owned companies. The Government, as the Deputy Prime Minister has said, will save $175 million through this cut. Employers are mostly grateful but also cynical that these cuts will significantly reduce job losses or bring in foreign investments or stop the outflow of investments.

    If this is the reality then, is this only a half measure? It would be a sorry day if employers bite the bullet only to make sacrifices for a short-term breather, a glitch on the globalisation radar screen. If we are seriously trying to lure MNCs back and be a serious contender against China and India, this CPF cut will only buy us a bit of time and slower the pace on retrenchments. But whether it will make us attractive enough is a moot point which I hope there will be further clarification on.

    Secondly, on the issue of land costs, DPM has already reassured that prices have fallen since 1994 by as much as 41%. But are we still cost competitive with other countries around us? We have already lost big clients to Malaysia and the very example cited by Minister Lim Boon Heng of Philips having moved its manufacturing plant to Batam is also another case in point - cheaper land and labour costs in Batam. Land costs, I think, need to be buffered differently for different industries here. As our retrenchments are most deep in the manufacturing sector then it is equally important to see how land costs can be reduced for such industries to carry on their work in Singapore and provide jobs.

    Another example is that if we aim to be the fashion centre of the east, then the

Column: 2861

retail sector needs a helping hand too. A Straits Times article last March showed that land costs for SMEs soaked up between 5% and 10% for the manufacturing sector while the bill for the retail sector was between 40% and 50%. Yes, land costs are coming down but we need to do more and be more creative too. We cannot afford to have any more white elephants if we can help it. An example in point would be to help small businessmen who are looking for cheaper rentals. Might it not be a better idea to rent out the old HDB HQ at Bukit Merah at a much reduced price or to also help the 49 aspiring business enthusiasts from the NTU's Technopreneurship Centre that Mr Raymond Lim spoke about last week? These are individuals who need a start-up hand or a helping hand with cheaper rentals. This Centre in Bukit Merah - right now I am not sure whether it is white or cream-coloured - can become a bustling centre, perhaps even called the Creative Business Centre, and who knows, in time to come, we might have a Sim Wong Hoo emerging with all credit going to HDB.

    Next, I would like to comment on the $1 billion relief package. It brought on a great sigh of relief that we do know that in spite of the cut, the people in different sectors will be taken care of.

    The Cut Waste Panel is an excellent idea and I hope the terms of reference here will include looking at processes and schemes and not just the smaller items, though they are equally important. Competition between health clusters and among hospitals has driven costs up, especially sometimes in terms of salary packages for clinicians. Competition among schools has also led to much out-doing of each other in terms of event management or brochure-ware to `sell' the schools. Competition among departments and across Ministries has also driven small launches into mini-stellar events.

    The argument then that they are sponsored, in my opinion, by corporate sponsors' money, does ring hollow at this point in time when this valuable money should go into the coffers of Community

Column: 2862

Chest or any other charity that is crying out to help the less privileged in our country. I am heartened that the civil service salaries will be reviewed as it is hard to know right now which market is driving up whose salaries - the private driving up the public or the public driving up the private. A clear example has been given by Minister Lim Boon Heng last week on the benchmarking across different work groups in that international table that he shared with us.

    On training, while we inject money to give more training for the vulnerable and the unemployed, may I also suggest that we redesign the job scope for Human Resource Departments. HRM and HRD (human resource development) in many companies are sometimes functioning as separate entities or entities with very loose links. HRMs need to be agile, imaginative and visionary. Often, they are still functioning quite primarily as hirers and firers when globalisation demands a new order that ought to include personalised career planning portfolios, constant job-redesigning and training. They need to be ahead of the curve like UPS and Hewlett Packard who have constantly redesigned jobs and offered the right kind of training so that retrenchment becomes hardly, if ever, necessary. It is an irony that our only natural resources - the human being, the worker - are led by HRMs that are sometimes not fast enough on the move and do not themselves have a clear job description on personnel enhancement, processes and outcomes and to remain ahead of the curve.

    On the aid schemes that were spelt out, I share Mr Iswaran's deep concern on attitudes towards people in need. He has expressed his views so eloquently that I will just add this to the discussion - that as we render aid to people in need we need to suspend our own judgment or sense of values. None of us will ever know what it is like unless we walk in the other person's shoes, as what Atticus said in the book "To Kill a Mockingbird". I think that is a lesson we can all remember when, through our frustration, we start passing on some of our value judgments to the person in need.

Column: 2863



    Secondly, it is vital to implement aid schemes well, with consistency and with expertise. Mr Ahmad Magad has already spoken on this need to have financial counselling. I would just push it a bit further to ask that it be a one-stop financial planning and counselling service to families in need such that what needs to be done can be mapped out against a time-line and all the aid schemes that are being offered and pegged to the training that they should be getting, plus what I am calling unofficially a "de-tox programme" to get rid of the problems that are stifling them or making them more dysfunctional year by year. With this time-line and constant monitoring, I think we will be able to get quite a number of our various aid schemes under a proper system of implementation which eventually should have an outcome that the family must move on and be better off.

    Thirdly, a query on the help schemes. The HOPE and the Small Families Interim Assistance Schemes have left the single parents in the cold. Then we ask why many among the single mothers do remarry and sometimes go on to have more children with their new spouses. Most of them, as data would show, are in the low income group. Many are also home-makers. Empowering such women takes time, training them for jobs will take longer when there is a conflicting demand on their time to look after the children. They also have a strong patriarchal mindset that men are the ones who should look after them. Given all these, it would be timely as social workers and VWOs work and get on with the educational programmes for these single parents. We should also back this with political will to help them to understand that people do come from different circumstances and not just review such cases on a case-by-case basis. In short, to me, the HOPE scheme and the rental policy do lack the vision in helping such families to get on and break out of the poverty cycle.

    I now turn to the two most vulnerable groups, in my opinion, who are in our

Column: 2864

midst. We need to think more long-term for them so that they do not become a social cost to the nation and their self-esteem is not compromised. I thank the Ministry of Manpower for giving me a very comprehensive reply to my Question on active and inactive CPF holders. From that data, there are 1.1 million inactive CPF account holders, of whom almost two-thirds are women. Among the active account holders of 1.3 million male members, there is a gross balance of about $110,000 while women have about $80,000. Women tend to live longer than the men and they have much less in their CPF. Many have dormant CPF accounts as a result of unemployment or being employed in the informal sector or being home-makers. We need to look into the CPF scheme to prop this up with various schemes that have been mentioned by Dr Jennifer Lee so that we can help these women and help them through the later years of their life.

    I would also like to ask if the CPF Board would like to consider perhaps an acknowledgment for this group of women who hold inactive CPF accounts that they be notified that their husbands are about to retrieve their retirement package so that at least they are aware how much money their husbands have accumulated and also plan with them, such that Batam becomes a figment of their imagination.

    The other group of people that I think we need to pay a little bit more attention to are the men and women in their late 40s to 50s - the sandwich generation is what we sometimes call them. They have been responsible family members taking care of their children, parents and, in some cases, grandparents. The data from the Manpower Ministry shows that men and women above 55 have an average net balance of about $30,000 and $23,000 respectively. I wonder what is going to be left for them to see through their retirement and old age. Inter-generational transfer of CPF savings has led to its own erosion for this group of account holders. The savings of this group of people too need some kind of shoring up so that they can tend to their health concerns as well as retirement.

Column: 2865



    Lastly, I would just like to say that in this whole CPF phenomenon, there is a whole group of people who have upgraded themselves constantly and may be caught in a jam. There have been reports in the papers of some of them earning about $2,000 vying for or living in a 5-room flat, and wondering how they are going to cope. While we try and put in these packages, etc, for the current group who is coming in, I think the financial counselling at the HDB end and at other various ends needs to be propped up so that people are very much in the know. As Singaporeans, we too have to realise what is the value system that we are holding on to that has just led us to upgrade and upgrade, and now we are caught in not so wonderful a position, in some cases.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to join in the debate.

    Today, I would like to address the issue of whether we have a real plan to address our economic woes and also how radical have we been in trying to address our economic problems that we are seeing right now. The Prime Minister mentioned that the CPF changes are the most radical ever made for a long time, but, with all due respect, Sir, I do not see the radical part of the changes. The lowering of the CPF rate by 3 percentage points is but a minor adjustment, in my opinion.

    Sir, the real issue is one of total cost. I would like to take up the analogy used by the Deputy Prime Minister, and that is, of the frog in the boiling water. What we have done with the CPF reduction by 3% is just like reducing the heating device a little, but it is hardly the cutting of all energy sources which are boiling the water. What we need are bold moves which will allow the frog to be energised to jump out of the pot of water. Or what we need is to cut off all the energy sources that are boiling the water so that the water never gets hot, and the frog will never die. The changes announced will just prolong our problems, in my opinion, because along with the CPF changes we need to do many other things. The much needed radical changes are nothing new and

Column: 2866

have been brought up by many Members before and also in the House over the last few days.

    These are: (1) the various Government charges and fees; (2) the cost of restructuring and retrenchments, which can discourage companies from wanting to set up base down here. And this is relevant because before companies come down here, they want to look at the whole life cycle and the day that they have to leave if they have to put up 24 months of retrenchments, it could discourage them from coming into Singapore; (3) rentals, utility charges, and many hidden taxes that I have talked about many times; and (4) the cost of regulatory compliance.

    Sir, on the way back from USA yesterday, I read about DPM's comments that the Government has already adequately addressed these cost issues. While I agree that something has been done, the changes are however not radical enough. What signals are we giving to employers and potential investors about the Government's resolve to address the total cost issues in Singapore when we do not go far enough in reducing the costs related to the factors that I mentioned earlier.

    Let me just take the cost of government as an example. The cost of government directly affects the Government charges and fees and also sets the stage for cost of doing business in Singapore. The Government is only now realising that there needs to be a cut waste system to cut waste in Government. In my opinion, cutting waste is not good enough. Waste, of course, should have been cut long time ago. We also need real cost reductions across the Government and its agencies, and not just in the area of waste. Even if it is just waste reduction, it shows that cost can be brought down some more. I am confident that if we look at the other factors, we probably can find opportunities for more cost reductions.

    I would like to relate my personal experience so that everyone would know that I am not just talking theory down here. I have started a number of companies. The first major one was a semiconductor

Column: 2867

company which I started in 1998. It is a manufacturing plant that employs about 1,000 people in Singapore right now. When I started it in 1998, I believed that Singapore could still be competitive in that industry. That company which I left, because it was already successful in its own right, is still around with about 1,000 employees but it is struggling to be competitive right now.

    In the year 2001, I started another semiconductor company. It now employs 1,500 employees but of these, only 11 are in Singapore right now; 350 in the USA, and more than 1,000 in the Philippines where we run our production, and about 60 in India where we do our design work. I tried my best to justify the setting up of a production facility in Singapore, but the other alternatives like Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia were more compelling. I still hope to create another 1,000 jobs in Singapore, but it must make sense and it is not about National Service for us, because we have to be alive for a long time and the competition is fierce and the cost can be a killer in Singapore. Had my management team made the wrong decision of forcing ourselves to set up a site in Singapore, we may not have been around today. So, if the Government can address all the cost and regulatory issues, I am confident that operating a large manufacturing site in Singapore for quite some time to come is possible. I know we can do it, if the Government gets the right formula implemented for cost reduction.

    Sir, the second issue is one of CPF, whether it should be compulsory or voluntary. If we look at countries which have gone through the same situation as Singapore before, particularly the developed countries that made their transition from not developed to being developed, I am sure we can get some good ideas, and one of them is a real radical move to make CPF less compulsory. Perhaps we can take the first step of breaking the CPF into two components - the first, compulsory; and the second, voluntary - supported by Government incentives to encourage employers and employees to voluntarily

Column: 2868

save for their retirement. At a 40% compulsory saving rate, employers have the flexibility to adjust only 80% of wages, which is what the employees take home. Also, about one-third of an employee's wage is compulsorily saved, thus reducing the amount available to drive the consumption part of our economy.

    I therefore suggest that we should move away from forcing Singaporeans and their employers with the statutory and compulsory saving regime. By all means, we should encourage savings for the future and for retirement, but let us make this a market-driven practice and the Government can play its part, not by forcing, but by incentivising.

    The truth of the matter is that while the 3% CPF cut is welcomed by companies, but when the companies faced the crunch over the last few years, they had already taken more aggressive moves like reducing wages by 10%, 20% or some, even 30%, depending on what it took them to survive in Singapore. This is the flexible part of the wages, while the CPF is the most inflexible part of the wage system because it is dictated by the Government. My opinion is that this issue of high forced saving rate is what is deterring companies from investing in Singapore. We have to change and follow what other developed countries do, and that is, to get away from this high forced saving rate and, therefore, reduce the Government's dominant role in determining the wage levels here. The market should be driving the decisions. Let us really cut the apron strings. Let us do away with the Government determining wages. Let us do away with the National Wages Council, which is another way of Government playing a dominant role in determining wages. Let it be market driven. It worked in the past, but it is not going to work in the future, in my opinion, for the changes that we are trying to make. The sooner we learn this new paradigm, the more successful we will be.

    Sir, the next issue is whether there is a plan for us to solve all our economic problems. Why is the Government pulling its punches? Half-hearted and piecemeal

Column: 2869

changes will prove counter-productive. We need the right mixture of ingredients to produce the right medicine which can be administered in the right dosages to cure our unemployment and economic problems. In my opinion, the CPF changes are but just one of the component ingredients and are not the final medicine which is so greatly needed right now. And if we think that CPF changes are going to solve all our problems, we are going to be mistaken.

    Sir, I fear one thing - two years down the road, after we have implemented the CPF changes, we will still be in the same position as today, because we did not make the other necessary changes. If we do not progress by then, Singaporeans will feel betrayed that the Government gave away their wages with no significant gain in return. Can we risk this happening in Singapore? The answer must surely be no. I hope that the Government is right. Time will tell if I am wrong about my assessment, and I hope I am wrong in this case. I urge the Government to reassess the situation with a much open mind. Please start believing the people and the private sector more, and I hope that we will find all the answers when they give their feedback.

    People ask me: does the Government really have a plan to get Singapore out of the current set of problems? Many feel that there is no real plan because CPF changes alone will not fix our problems. This is the feedback I have been getting from the ground. In this respect, can I ask the Prime Minister to share with the House the reasons why companies are packing up and leaving Singapore? Surely, it is not because the CPF is just 3% too high. I am sure that there are many more factors which are forcing companies to pack up and leave. What are these factors and what are we doing about them? I know of a few multi-national companies which are still planning to exit Singapore today. They are still here, but they are planning their exit. The momentum of companies leaving Singapore has not slowed down and unless and until we address the cost factors adequately, we will continue to shed jobs and lose companies.

Column: 2870



    If the Government can share with all of us what these exiting companies are saying, perhaps we can be convinced that there is a good plan in place and that we can solve all of our problems. Currently, there are many sceptics - they are not yet convinced that we have a plan that will work.

    Sir, in conclusion, I would like to urge the leaders to come up with a convincing plan which can assure and also inspire the people of Singapore to rally around the Government to solve all our economic woes. It is not just about waiting and seeing the outcome a few years from now, but to give confidence to everyone that we can do it. I am convinced that if we take all the necessary radical steps, we can do it. But I have not seen all the necessary steps personally. We need the Government to be bold and more entrepreneurial than what they have done before. I hope that we will not be disappointed and that the economy recovers fast enough so that jobs remain in Singapore and the unemployment situation gets resolved quickly.

    The Minister of State for Defence (Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng) : Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for this opportunity to join in the debate. I would like to share my views, especially from my perspective as Chairman, SPRING Singapore.

    Many Members of this House have pointed out that the broader challenge confronting Singapore is not just about the retuning of the Central Provident Fund but how Singapore can continue to be competitive in the global marketplace. It is about our ability to create good jobs so that Singaporeans can chase their Singapore dreams.

    Let me briefly discuss the CPF changes.

    The 3% CPF cut and the lowering of the CPF contribution ceiling are significant to tackle our wage rigidity to respond to our immediate challenges but of greater significance are the changes that we are making to the withdrawal rules and Minimum Sums. The benefits of these CPF changes we are making now will largely be felt 10 years from now. For the first

Column: 2871

time, the CPF and Medisave Minimum Sums will be adjusted for inflation. They will provide a basic level of financial security for retired Singaporeans. Mr Inderjit Singh suggested that perhaps a part of the CPF contribution should be made voluntary. However, in reality, it is not so simple. Singapore's Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is at a 26-year low of 1.38. Soon, a small base of young Singaporeans will be supporting a very large group of retirees. This "inverse pyramid" will be very unstable unless we require that every Singaporean put aside sufficient funds for his own healthcare and retirement needs. Otherwise, the burden on our future generations will be untenable. And at that time, taxes will have to increase. Singapore can no longer be an attractive place to work or live in. Many of our more capable youths will be drawn to countries offering lower taxes.

    The changes to withdrawal rules and Minimum Sums will underpin Singapore's competitiveness for the long haul and it is more significant than many have thought.

    Let me move on to discuss what else may be needed for Singapore to enhance its competitiveness. Lowering wage cost with a new CPF rate is a necessary but insufficient condition to regain our overall competitiveness. From the perspective of labour cost competitiveness alone, the odds are stacked against Singapore. The Prime Minister and Minister Lim Boon Heng have cited the wages of a manufacturing worker in Singapore compared to other emerging and competing economies.     In reality, in a competitive environment, lower cost of production, as a result of higher productivity, will lead to lower prices for the products and will stimulate higher demand and therefore more products are sold. Soon, higher capacity is needed and more jobs are created. Even if the productivity surplus were distributed to shareholders, such surplus will be invested in other sectors of the economy or end up as higher consumption. Then they went on to operate double-decked buses with twice the capacity but with the same one driver. Productivity doubled again.     The Acting Minister for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): First of all, let me thank Members for supporting these changes.

Ms Indranee Rajah will be pleased to know that common sense indeed was used in plentiful dollops. For while the reasons for and pace of CPF changes have been accepted by the majority, this moment at the crossroads has occasioned all Singaporeans to wonder about our future, our needs and our fates. There is even fear among some Singaporeans. They are asking if these changes signal an end to the Singaporean dream; a relegation from our first world status; an end to some aspirations and hopes.

of Parliament. To me, there is the greater significance of character and nation-building in this exercise. Our responses to these changes should be seen in this context as it signals a people's - a nation's - resolve, to want to chart and better their destiny.

They say cutting CPF will dampen the recovery as consumer expenditure falls and the property market softens due to reduced purchasing power. A deflationary cycle will follow. that shows the resolve to do what is needed; to be nimble and to adjust, as Dr Tan Cheng Bock said. It signals a nation on the move, willing to make sacrifices to survive.     Many Members have asked for a clear economic plan. The Prime Minister will elaborate on this tomorrow. But as many Members also know, where it comes to matters of business, as it does affairs of the heart, it is not so simple. It is not so completely deterministic. There is no magic formula. But we can learn from others. There are some general ingredients for success.

    History is replete with examples of countries that were content to lie in the present, resisting change and landed on the slippery slope because they chose not to confront their problems and new realities head-on. On this, I agree with Mr Inderjit Singh that we have to tackle our problems head-on.

    China has a particularly venerable history. It boasted inventions such as printing and paper in the ninth century, gunpowder in the 11th century, the compass, porcelain. The Chinese invented machines to spin hemp in the 12th century, some 500 years before the Industrial Revolution began in England. China had the knowledge capital and advantage over many countries. With its inventions, it could have been the first to print books for the masses to accelerate learning. It could have experienced its own industrial revolution. With gunpowder, it could have revolutionised the science of propulsion for industry or military gains.

    It could have but then China - the self-absorbed Celestial empire - closed its

Column: 2912

minds to progress and its own strengths and opportunities and became insular. From the 15th century, other nations pulled ahead. So for the last 500 years, China lumbered along, living on past glory. But the dragon has stirred and all in its wake felt the pounding of its steps when it threw open its doors and chose to engage the modern world.

    Japan's income rose from 20% of the United States' in 1950 to 75% by 1998. It is a rise unparalleled in recorded history. This phoenix rose miraculously from its atomic ashes and dazzled the world with its manufacturing prowess. But in the last two decades, when faced with much lesser challenges, it lacked that same resolve to pull itself out of its quagmire.

    From 750 to 1100 AD, Islamic science and technology far surpassed that of Europe. In their golden years, the world's greatest scientists wrote in Arabic. Indeed during that period, many Muslims taught science to Europeans, especially at the frontiers like Spain where intermixing occurred. Then something went wrong. Religious zealots denounced Islamic science as heresy. These nations regressed as they chose a parochial emphasis on religious conformity.

    Any group or nation - no matter how mighty - that discards knowledge, prefers form over substance, sacrifices future needs for present comforts, resists change, erects barriers to progress, is doomed to fail. Ultimately, these barriers are self-destructive.

    Economic historians, such as Stephen Parente and Edward Prescott in their book "Barriers to Riches" tell us that the differences in living standards have little to do with natural resources - or levels of investment. Rather, they see the differences in the intensity that various countries make of the world's existing stock of know-how. Countries that are open to the flow of ideas - and whose laws, customs and institutions encourage wealth creation - can catch up with the old-established "industrial" economies. Japan, Korea and recently China are outstanding examples of this catch-up.

    In other words, while all countries will walk through hills and valleys, some walk right into ravines or get mired in swamps. Others stay still and get hemmed in and suffocated by the overgrowth. Those that erect barriers, both physical and mental, will be overtaken. Only those who choose to engage progress wholeheartedly, expand their minds and economic space, survive and thrive.

    What about the million dollar question that many MPs have asked? Even if Singapore is willing to change, will these changes be enough? Who does fortune favour? While history teaches us that nations that do not change are often overtaken, it also shows us that "fortune favours the well prepared." Tenacity, diligence, boldness and a cohesive spirit have helped nations, in more dire circumstances than Singapore is today, pull themselves out of the rut. I will give two examples and use city-states for comparability.

    Take Ireland as the first example. In 1840, the Irish population was nine million but, a decade later, it was halved: over a million died of starvation; most emigrated; a quarter of those who boarded the ill-fated coffin ships to America died in transit. After emerging as the Irish Free State, it promptly plunged into a civil war that lasted until 1923. At that time, the population included fewer than three million people and was still dwindling. In other words, they lost six million people in 80 years.

    To demonstrate economic "self-sufficiency" as well as political independence, Ireland adopted inward-looking, protectionist policies - high tariffs, bans on majority foreign ownership in industry, the establishment of state-owned enterprises in areas such as power generation, shipping, banking and insurance. These policies were pursued well into the 1950s, with increasingly perverse results. The economy stagnated, emigration soared even further, as more than 400,000 people left Ireland between 1951 and 1961. In the mid-80s, the unemployment rate reached 17%, the government's finances were in shambles, and submission to a draconian

Column: 2914

International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme was considered as a means of getting the economy back on track.

    But something happened. At the end of the year 2000, Ireland could look back on 14 years of uninterrupted economic growth, which had accelerated to nearly 10% annually. With this growth came markedly lower inflation, one of the lowest unemployment rates in the European Union, and a growing government-budget surplus. Most dramatic, however, was the return to Ireland, a country which had seen emigration over 100 years, of young workers in increasing numbers to fill new jobs awaiting them at home.

    How did they reverse their terrible plight? It was not just due to the luck of the Irish. In the 1960s that tenacious Irish spirit rallied. The government and people decided to adopt low corporate tax rates to encourage foreign investments. At a time when they could least afford, they spent more on educating their people better and establish high-tech industries, especially in info-technology and telecommunications. Ireland joined the European Union. In the 1990s, true to the aphorism that "fortune favours the well prepared", a technological discontinuity, which brought about plummeting costs in telecommunication services, was the chance element that helped start an economic boom in Ireland.

    My second example is Finland. Finland is another example of a tenacious people that refused to be beaten down. Tucked away in the northern-most corner of Europe, five million dedicated Finns continue to demonstrate the fierce nationalism that has enabled them to survive an unforgiving climate as well as a turbulent history. It is a land repeatedly fought over through the centuries. Finland underwent a transition from frozen isolation along the Arctic Circle into a centre of high technology, with a population both technologically literate and politically sophisticated.

    Twice in the 20th century, Finland had been written off as lost: first, in the "Winter War" in 1939 when the Finns were

Column: 2915

left alone to face invasion by a Russian army 50 times its size, and again at the end of World War II when Finland was given over to the Soviet sphere of influence. In the early 1990s, the Soviet empire fragmented and the Rouble collapsed. Finland's economy, which was closely tied to that of the Soviet Union, also shrank sharply and unemployment rose. Yet, it has managed to come out of its troubles.

    How? Government and industry made dramatic efforts to surge into the world's new information technology, supported by one of the most highly skilled labour forces in the world. Finland, today, is rightly called the telecommunications laboratory of the European Union, with an exceptional hi-tech infrastructure. Many of us know as we use their Nokia phones. This, in addition to industrial production ranging from complex instrumentation for meteorological and environmental sciences, to medical diagnostic equipment, to automated wood-harvesting machinery, to innovative icebreakers and luxurious cruise ships. In the late 1990s, Finland's economic growth rate was one of the highest of the industrialised countries.

But global economic shifts have accelerated and impacted Singapore almost instantaneously. In this fluid environment, we need flexibility, even for the statutory component. It will come under pressure the moment you fix it. And when you are compelled to lower it, the psychological effect is greater. Remember also that even when we had fixed it at 40%, it also caused uncertainty. While we were at 36%, investors and employers calculated decisions based on that higher target rate. Workers based aspirations and lifestyles

also on that number, assuming it would be restored.

Heng Ching and Mr Ng Ser Miang - of using tax incentives to encourage companies to reform. The Task Force will be presenting its recommendations at the end of the year, and will consider other proposals which Mr Inderjit Singh brought up this afternoon on retrenchment cost.

Providing better for retirement

Housing is the biggest asset for most Singaporeans and the Minister has announced relaxation on rental rules and it should help. We have explored reverse mortgages before, but the major roadblock has been that insurers are only prepared to offer "fixed term" reverse mortgage.

This runs the risk of the elderly lessees being evicted from their flats should they outlive the tenure of their reverse mortgages, which is a likely possibility. Nevertheless, we can always revisit the issue.

    The other option is for Singaporeans to sell their properties. DBS Bank pays only 0.8% for a one-year fixed deposit of more than $50,000 and 0.25% for savings account deposits. So, if we use this formula, I should be paying OA rate of less than 1%. This includes the promotion of the use of the Supplementary Retirement Scheme, as suggested by Mr Ahmad Magad and Dr Mohamad Maliki.

    For specific groups, women and homemakers, suggested by Ms Irene Ng, Dr Jennifer Lee and Ms Braema Mathi, we will explore ways to improve their retirement adequacy.

    For part-time and casual workers, the point brought up by Dr Gan See Khem, the CPF Board has already implemented the ERC's recommendation to raise the floor for CPF contribution from the earlier threshold range of $200-$363 to a new threshold range of $500-$750. But I agree with Mr Zainudin Nordin that we should facilitate collection of CPF dues. The late payments form less than 1% of all accounts, but we can still improve by collecting CPF through electronic means. We will expedite this.

Retaining Jobs, Job Redesign, Placements and Training

    I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Nithiah Nandan, Dr Wang Kai Yuen, Mr Heng Chee How, Mr Yeo Guat Kwang and Mr Ang Mong Seng that we should use these sacrifices that workers have made to translate to more jobs. The CPF changes will position us well for job creation. At the margins, it already has positive signals and, again, we should not diminish our efforts. For example, Venture Corporations and Philips Electronics Singapore both welcome the changes. Venture Corporations told our staff that

Column: 2925

together with their efforts to improve their employees' capabilities and skills, these CPF cuts will "give a boost to migrating more businesses and investments to Singapore".

    But in the meantime, we must redouble our efforts to place Singaporeans in jobs. We have to work faster to develop sectors that Singapore can be competitive.

    Secondly, all of us must do more to place Singaporeans in jobs that are available today - points brought up by Dr Warren Lee and Mr Ang Mong Seng. They said that we should raise again the importance of local workers being willing to take menial tasks. I agree. But we have also seen good evidence of worker attitude changing in the past half year. And I agree with Mr Nithiah Nandan that not all workers are choosy. We must not tar all workers with the same brush. For instance, many cleaning companies have told us that they can now hire locals for cleaning jobs and they do not need to ask for so many foreign workers. This is good news.

    But there is much more that we can do. We have come to a point where MOM goes down to the ground - you should allow your policy instruments to do that - but we recognise this is a transitionary period and we want to get a better feel of the ground. During one of our dialogues, a unionist told me that some Singaporeans dare not work in hotel kitchens because they feel isolated, as they are the only Singaporeans there, or that the supervisor is a foreigner and is perceived to be partial to hiring more foreigners. It is unlikely to be true, but it is a perception. We must and will break these psychological barriers down. My Ministry has been working closely with the hotel sector to better understand how to successfully place Singaporeans into jobs in this sector which has so many vacancies. The hotel management assures us that they are committed to help make this happen. In parallel, I have asked union leaders of NTUC unions to get their members to mentor new workers. In other words, let us accept the insecurity and the uncertainty. So, from the over 400,000

Column: 2926

members that NUTC has, members can perhaps find mentors that stay in the same estate with the new workers, travel, eat together in the same company so that during the earlier adjustment period, it will tide them over and help them to stay in the job.

    And, yes, we should improve the efficiency of job matching and information provision. The Workforce Development Agency (WDA) will be launched soon to give this greater focus. As suggested by Mr Seng Han Thong, we will have to make sure that training is more effective. And I agree with Dr Tan Cheng Bock that we have to upgrade our skills in our construction, retail and restaurants.

    Some Members have asked that we look for solutions, in terms of social safety net in force. But when we are in a situation where there are large numbers of foreign workers and jobs available that Singaporeans do not want to take, I believe that we should focus on the message of getting people into jobs, not subsidising people for not working. And the measures that DPM announced on Friday, such as the Training for Employment scheme, the People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme, the Work Assistance Programme, hold to this philosophy.

    I agree also that employers must play their part. And I am glad that the Singapore National Employers' Federation and the Singapore Business Federation have come out in strong support for these cuts. We all understand that the business climate is competitive. But there are many employers that we have come across that are competitive and, yet, treat their workers well. As Mr Ahmad Khalis says, retrenchment should be minimised. There should be less discrimination against older workers, a point raised by Mr Nithiah Nandan. The cost of hiring mature workers would be less because of these CPF changes, and older workers bring value through their experience and networking. They are also likely to stay longer on their jobs.

    We have good employers in Singapore. You may have read about Murata Singapore. It has been in Singapore for over 30

Column: 2927

years. I visited them at the National Day Observance Ceremony and they told me they had not retrenched a single worker for the last 30 years. I thought they got it wrong. I asked, "Are you sure?" They said, "Yah, we don't. We have not retrenched a single worker." So, in good times, a company rewards the workers well with additional bonuses. But in bad times, they adjust various flexible schemes.

    Ms Braema Mathi brought up a point about United Parcel Services (UPS). And she is right. It is a good company with enlightened human resource practices. UPS, led by Singaporean Managing Director, Mary Yeo, has encouraged multi-tasking and emphasised career development for their van drivers. During SARS, workers willingly worked flexible hours.

    Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon has highlighted that we should tailor our solutions for older workers to upgrade their skills and find jobs. We agree. Companies must play their part to accommodate older workers who may be able to do the job very well. One HR manager told us that her company had problems with production in some of the plants. This is on a productivity issue. But this observant HR manager noted that workers were standing because of the height of the production line, and that shorter workers had difficulty doing the work because the line was too high for them. Minor adjustment was all that was needed to raise productivity. This sounds simple, but simple things are often not done. So this story should cheer Mr Seng Han Thong who called on companies to help local workers through job redesign. We all agree, and more can be done.

    But apart from wages and jobs, at the end of this debate, the question that will still remain in our minds is: will Singapore prosper again? Mr Tan Soo Khoon said that the music had died for him in 1998. Will Singapore prosper again? It depends. It depends on whether Singaporeans think our way of life is worth preserving. It depends if Singaporeans think this

Column: 2928

place is worth fighting for, not with bullets of steel but with steely resolve, an innovative spirit to capitalise on our strengths, diligence and determination.

    Is the Singapore Dream dead? As Mark Twain said, the news of the demise has been grossly exaggerated. Far from it. This doctor has examined the patient and found it well. The patient is not sick. She only needs to shed a few pounds. Too many good years and over-indulgence have added girth. Some weight trimming is necessary and may not be bad for overall health.

    Even with the contribution rate at 30%, the majority of Singaporeans can own homes and retire adequately with their medical and retirement needs taken care of, if they are prudent. As I earlier showed, even the 25th percentile worker can still afford a 4-room flat and would have provided enough for his medical and retirement needs till 80. How many countries can achieve that?

    Almost every child born in Singapore today can be certain of 12 years of solid education. Mr Ong Ah Heng joked that perhaps the Government should just kelong and give 4-D tickets to Singaporeans. In fact, we have. Let me tell you why. Every student is subsidised about $4,000 for each year in primary school, $6,000 in secondary school, $8,000 in ITE, Junior College or polytechnic, and $11,000 in university. This means that every child born in Singapore receives at least $60,000 in education subsidies. This is not including the housing subsidy. 70% will obtain higher education that is the passport anywhere in the world to further his study. Access to good medical care will continue to be available to the masses, not only to the privileged or the rich. Here, in Singapore, you walk the streets feeling much safer than in many other countries. Children grow up well here. We, the adults, spend half the time debating why we spoil them, and the other half asking why we stress them. The same debate will be continued by our children when they become adults.

    Why do I believe so emphatically that Singapore will not only overcome but

Column: 2929

that we will prosper further? The music has not stopped. Because Singaporeans will not falter. Years of nation building have bonded a people with unique characteristics. Shared pains and gains have created a uniquely Singaporean way, that is, a way of life that is worth preserving - with all its quirks and eccentricities.

    I agree with Dr Tan Cheng Bock that Singaporean can do. His ingrained beliefs in hard work, justice, integrity are universal premiums. I travel frequently and I meet many Presidents of Ivy League universities in USA. They tell me that there is only one thing wrong with Singaporean students - that there are not enough of them. They say this even though Singapore students form the largest contingent from any state, including the states of the United States. They want more of us. They wax lyrical about how they wish every freshman performed like our Singaporeans. Of course, in typical Asian humility, I respond by saying, "Well, we have some strengths, but many weaknesses too." But, inwardly, when they tell me this, I swell with pride.

    CEOs of multi-national corporations here in the biopharmaceutical and process industry sectors tell that we have among the best technical workers in the world. They have one wish - that Singaporeans would be less driven, because many of them leave to further their education, not content to stay still. But I like this drive.

    Singapore companies tell us that two positions, when they go overseas, must be occupied by Singaporeans, ie, the manager and the financial controller. Why? No prizes for those who guess the reason - because they trust Singaporeans. Despite the catch-up of other countries, like China and India, we can still hold our own in technical and engineering skills. Our efforts in educating Singaporeans still stand us in good stead. Do not under-estimate these strengths nor our ability to read these changes.

    Am I overly optimistic? Do I not fear the tiger of globalisation, the challenges that Members paint and the companies tell us? Well, when a tiger is chasing you, you

Column: 2930

need not be the fastest to survive. Just run fast enough so that there is one other person for the tiger to satisfy his hunger. We have built up our strengths in these past years to run well. With these CPF and wage reforms, we would have further lightened our loads. We are well positioned to avoid hazards and pitfalls. If we continue on this new road, expand our minds to see possibilities and capitalise on our strengths and opportunities, we will prosper.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I refer to the table distributed by the Acting Minister. It shows that the 25th percentile of workers should have no problem meeting their housing, Medisave and retirement needs, at the CPF contribution rate of 30%. I wonder why the Acting Minister has chosen the 25th percentile of workers, as I understand the CPF covers from the 20th to 80th percentile of workers. So what is the situation at the lowest 20th percentile? Are they able to meet their needs?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: These calculations hold, which means that even at 30%, 85% to 90% of Singaporeans can own at least a 3-room flat. I have just used the 25th and 50th percentile. If I have put the 10th, 20th to 80th percentile, it will confuse us. But if the Member wants the details, we can distribute it from every percentile at 10 points.

    Mr Chandra Mohan K Nair (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak on this topic of retuning the CPF pursuant to the Prime Minister's Ministerial Statement on 28th August.

    The legislative history of the Central Provident Act dates back to the Central Provident Fund Ordinance of 1953 (Ordinance 34 of 1953) and it commenced on 1st July 1955. "Provident" means seeing beforehand and providing for the future;

Column: 2931

being prudent, thrifty and frugal. Our CPF Act and its predecessor legislation, during and prior to the PAP coming into power, have, in some way, made compulsory saving of citizen's moneys to form the Central Provident Fund and out of which authorised payments are made. On the whole, it has brought a great deal of advantages to our citizens and working population in Singapore. It has also brought a large amount of money to our Government and, hopefully, it has been used to invest and reap some good returns. It would be ideal if these, or some of these returns, could be ploughed back to CPF account holders as a whole.

    The website of CPF Board provides that the mission of CPF is "to enable Singaporeans to save for a secure retirement". And its vision is that of "a world-class social security organisation providing the best national savings scheme for Singaporeans to enjoy a secure retirement". The emphasis has always been savings for our retirement. Our Government must guide our people to ensure that, as far as possible, the retirement needs of the majority of our citizens would be met. It would be in the Government's interest to ensure this because, if there is a great shortfall in this CPF scheme, the Government, being a responsible one, would have to lean towards a more "welfare-oriented" and socialist political system which the PAP Government tries to avoid directly as far as possible.

    The corporate philosophy of CPF is, and I quote:

    "a social security savings scheme jointly supported by employees, employers and the Government. CPF members are employees and self-employed persons in Singapore.

    The basic purpose of the CPF is to help members meet primary needs like shelter, food, clothing and health services in their old age or when they are no longer able to work. Benefits offered are to help meet one or more needs of the CPF member in his retirement. They include withdrawals by the member for retirement, permanent disablement, home ownership and medical care. The amounts available depend on how much the member has saved in the CPF.

    The CPF Board is the trustee of members' CPF savings. They seek to protect and preserve the value

Column: 2932

of the savings. They provide fair market returns at minimal risk, while opening avenues for members to seek higher returns on their own after carefully considering the risks involved. The guiding principle is prudence. Any return should contribute towards the member's well-being in his retirement."

    Sir, it would appear that the above stated philosophy may need to be modified in difficult economic times. The Prime Minister touched on globalisation and how it has continued to affect our economy. There are advantages and disadvantages in globalisation. The two giant nations, China and India, with over 2 billion people, are and will be, population-wise and business-wise, forces to be reckoned with in the premier league of nations in the global economic arena. Singapore can try but realistically would find it very difficult to be in the premier league because, in terms of population base and business base, production of goods and services, invention and information technology, manufacturing of high-end technological products, production of university scholars, scientists, inventors, engineers, doctors, architects or any professional groupings, political leaders and tertiary professors and, in many other respects, touching on economic and other considerations, it is realistically impossible.

    However, Singapore must and will no doubt do its level best to survive comfortably and progress in the face of all the competition from near and far. And since we have reached first-world standard, economically speaking, our citizenry would expect that standard of living in the years to come. Singaporeans would have a tough time trying to aspire to reach this target as the years go by. We have a disciplined and hardworking population that will fight hard to advance as the years go by. We have a good Government, civil service, judiciary, rule of law, caring nation with many voluntary and Government-sponsored community of volunteers. All these good institutions have served us well the last few decades and will continue to do so. But is it sufficient in the future?

    The Government should have and must have known all this was coming many

Column: 2933

years ago. The citizens knew and constantly talked and complained about the high cost of business in Singapore. This is not new at all. On hindsight, perhaps the Government should have acted earlier, even before the General Elections in 2001. At least, we are now trying to make amends. It is never too late. Let us all work together as Singaporeans. I believe our Government is trying hard, but more needs to be done by one and all.

    Temporary measures require us to be cost-effective. This means we have to cut down on CPF and all other forms of cost-cutting measures. We have to be lean and fit for a race that is going to be very competitive for the next few years. CPF cuts alone would not be a great help in bringing in more investments from abroad and locally and, therefore, more employment for our people. However, it is a strong signal to the world looking at Singapore, as a country to invest in, that our Government is trying to cut down on business costs. More cost-cutting measures must be put in place sooner than later. And this is essential and is an emergency, as a lot of businesses from Singapore and the ASEAN countries are going especially to China and India. And it is well possible that there would be even more competition in the business world, as Malaysia and other ASEAN countries move on progressively to catch up with the rest of the world.

    It is a race between premier league nations, Divisions 1, 2 and 3 and amateur teams, with the same set of rules and there are no handicaps given to small nations. Singapore must find innovative ways to be in the top league. How do top premier league players stay on top? They devise various means, including looking at the world's best players and managers, training them professionally and paying them well. We also need to look at not just the best companies and top-notch entrepreneurs, but also the potential nations as business and economic partners. Our Cabinet Ministers and top Government officials have to be much more innovative henceforth and come up with revolutionary ideas, which is possible only if they are willing to think out of the ordinary

Column: 2934

and long-practised ways of dealing with the business of governing Singapore. I trust they are looking into various possibilities, as we have a Government that is pragmatic and is a long-term planner. Citizens must assist in this regard by giving innovative ideas, which may be idealistic and/or practical. It is our duty as citizens to help our Government to lead it to the right path of progress.

    Our mindset and tactics must, if found necessary and essential, change in order to survive well, to be competitive and to create jobs in Singapore. We are a small nation geographically and population-wise. We do not have natural resources. There are a lot of disadvantages in that sense, compared to many nations in ASEAN, Asia and the world. What can we do really?

    Let us think out of the box. Theoretically speaking, one could therefore ask whether being a sovereign nation called the "Republic of Singapore" is the ideal state of affairs in, say, 20 or 30 years. Can we survive as a small nation when ASEAN countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam and Thailand are forging ahead at a different pace of economic progress? They are hungry for economic progress, just as we were hungry in the 1960s to the 1990s, and we progressed at a faster pace during this period, as we had to survive, which definitely was an added and essential impetus to survive as a young nation. I am sure we can and will survive as a nation for another decade or two comfortably. However, would we want to consider, and do we have a new vision of joining forces politically, geographically and economically with some ASEAN countries? Is it possible to work together as ASEAN neighbours and let us share the pie as a joint venture company of nations?

    We were once part of Malaysia from 1963 to 1965. We became a sovereign republic on 9th August 1965. What would we have been if we had remained in Malaysia? We can only speculate. Historians should write about it and explain to the citizenry. Let us now speculate and perhaps give deep analytical thought on

Column: 2935

having Singapore, Malaysia and perhaps even some other ASEAN countries merge in some form to create a United States of South East Asia, if not absolutely, then at least economically, and all of us in ASEAN work together and share part of our assets, manpower, time and expertise. It is like forming a holding company, and each participating country being a subsidiary, and all working together in harmony and all reaping the benefits of our collective efforts to benefit all as a family.

    Team effort is what is required to match the premier league players. Additionally or alternatively, we should all put on our thinking caps and consider the possibility of joining, in an economic sense, the premier league players like China and India. Our closest relationship as a nation to nation is of course Malaysia, and then comes perhaps Indonesia. At first thought, everything might seem impossible, what with the history of political leadership having had their problems, especially in the 1960s. However, today's generation of political leaders must bury the old differences, even if some of the current leaders in Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore might be related to the older leaders of these countries. The business community and citizens of Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore would, I suspect, want as close a relationship as possible, both in terms of political, economic and family ties. Would it not be important, therefore, for the political leaders, especially from these three countries in ASEAN, to work harder and more productively towards this goal of merger as ASEAN has existed for more than three decades.

    Let us take advantage of the common factors like race, language and way of life amongst our peoples. We have Malays, Chinese, Indians and Eurasians, just like in Malaysia and Indonesia, and also in China and India, as far as the Chinese and Indians respectively are concerned. I know it may be idealistic and even unrealistic to think of such a possibility today, but we sow the seeds of such thoughts in our young leaders and they have to explore all avenues to survive, and who knows

Column: 2936

what may come out of this way of thinking for our future generations of citizens, who would be more global in outlook in the years to come. Mind you, this does not mean people who think this way are disloyal but, rather, I believe it is the citizens who dare to think boldly that would make the difference for the betterment of Singapore in 20 or 30 years.

    If we want to survive for the next few decades, we need to open up space - have dual or multi-citizenship, and have multi-national partners in business and as nations doing business, and not just companies and Government-linked companies. Politicians need to be more innovative, just like company directors have for the last 30 years or so. Companies are going global. Governments should consider at least going regional politically. The political system needs to be relooked and a new system adopted for discussion at least. Our Government has done well for our citizens and the nation for the last 40 years. We need to do much more, and it is going to be more difficult, because the competition is much keener. It is getting more difficult to grow since we are a first-world nation, and to maintain that in the midst of keen competition is going to be that much tougher.

    Article 6 of the Constitution of Singapore states that there shall be no surrender of the sovereignty of Singapore as an independent nation unless it is supported at a national referendum by not less than two-thirds of the citizens who can vote. Academically speaking, for a start, we may wish to consider this in the long-term remaking of Singapore. If the Government has not thought about it, or has done so but it is of the view that it is definitely not possible to have such thoughts to come to reality, I would urge that we get the reasoned paper on why it is not possible in the long term. I know the CPF issue is in the spotlight, but what I have mentioned is food for thought to try and, hopefully, resolve our larger problem of survival economically as a nation. I suppose these must, for the time being, be left aside, but I do sincerely hope that our Government and leaders in the business and academic community would

Column: 2937

address these issues at some stage in the near future.

    For now, let us all unite and come up with cost-effective measures to ensure creation of more jobs and secure reasonable remuneration and contribution into our citizens' CPF, so that all retirement needs, payments like housing and medical care, can be met.

    Equally important, sacrifices must be made by the State, Government and civil service expenditure, cooperation from banks and financial institutions, to be more compassionate and not to exercise their legal rights without some care and concern for the plight of citizens. The lifelines to be given by the Government to the poorer sectors of our society who may be most hard-hit by the CPF cuts are to be welcome. This is the usual "Robin Hood" approach of taking - some might call it "robbing" - from the rich and distributing it to the poor. It is noble and should be palatable to Singapore society as a whole. However, the Government should, once in a while, take note of and be caring and compassionate, even if it is to be lip service, to the lower-middle and middle class of citizens who may be complaining that they are often left out.

    Land costs, rentals, utilities charges, GST, licensing charges, income tax, property tax, etc, must be reviewed and lowered. Let the State suffer together with citizens. Let us all share in the financial burden. My colleagues in Parliament have addressed these issues several times during the last two sittings last week.

    The CPF Board should also consider investing CPF monies wisely and grant members better interest rates. Mr Lee Han Shih, a freelance journalist, had mentioned in his article in Today on 28th August 2003 that the CPF Act should be amended so that members can enjoy higher interest rates by allowing computation of interest on a daily, rather than on a monthly basis. The CPF should look into this and explain why it has not done so.

    Overall, I am of the view that cost cutting must cover a wider ambit than CPF cost cutting alone. A holistic approach

Column: 2938

must be taken to reduce business costs. However, this move to cut CPF rates at this stage is a good sign to investors to have added confidence to remain here and for fresh investors to come to invest in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do support the Prime Minister's call to cut the CPF rate in order to create more investments in Singapore and more jobs for our citizens.

    Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for the opportunity to join in the debate.

    The Government should be applauded for coming out with a comprehensive and directed dosage of measures to help those who are affected by the adjustment in CPF contributions, and also for the additional package to assist businesses, particularly the construction, tourism and SMEs. DPM Lee's announcement, in fact, does address many of the concerns of the people and businesses. It is a reflection of our commitment to look after the interest of the country and the people.

    The measures introduced will have very long-term benefits for our workers. Yes, they have to tighten their belts now, relook their financial planning, but their future will be better secured. The measures will help the workers to stand up and proudly move forward. It is our policy to teach and equip a man to catch his own fish, rather than to give him fish every day and he does not know how to fish.

    However, there are a few concerns on the Work Assistance Programme for

Column: 2939

the unemployed, and the People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme for older workers. Many do have family problems that come along with unemployment for a period of time, eg, family violence, potential legal proceedings for traffic and parking fines, credit cards, utilities bills, or even bankruptcy suits. We need more than a case manager to assist the unemployed and the older workers. We need a comprehensive network of social services to deal with these family matters. And I suggest that the localised Family Service Centres, with the support of the CDCs, work together with the case manager to extend professional guidance to these families.

    Secondly, these schemes should also look into providing additional financial schemes during the period of training. For example, get them involved in the child/student care financial assistance scheme, where they can put their children in the child/student care centres, and parents would be more willing to go for skills upgrading knowing that their children are taken care of.

    As for the setting up of the Public Transport Funds for the lower-income families, I would urge the Government and NTUC to extend this help to the marginal groups of families which hover between the low and middle income. I have in mind especially the cases where the breadwinners are in the older age group and they are hardest hit by the CPF adjustment. These families tend to have children in the teenage group, where they are socially active and need public transport to move around, and many of these families have also supported the Government's call to have more than two children. We sincerely hope that the qualifying family income level eligible for the transport fund assistance be realistically set to readily help those who need help, rather than by an exception to the prescribed guidelines.

    On the Government's help for businesses by extending the statutory lifespan of omnibuses and taxis, may I also ask the DPM to consider extending the 10-year

Column: 2940

cap for motorcars to 12 years so that the man-in-the-street need not scrap his car within a short period of time. Often, Singaporeans take good care of their cars and with improved technology, the cars are still roadworthy after 10 years. It is an argument that DPM has used for the extension of the lifespan of buses and taxis. It is a waste to have to scrap the cars. A change in this 10-year cap will help many people, who need a car for their businesses and work. This has also been thoroughly argued by Mr Tan Soo Khoon earlier on the high cost of owning a car.

    I am particularly pleased to note that the Government is setting up a Cut Waste Panel. A lot of Members have said why not a No Waste Panel. I believe that the coverage extends to the civil service and statutory boards. Government Ministries and statutory boards should not lose sight of their basic objective, that is, what is their mission. Their task is to provide a very noble service, ie, to provide public service at an effective cost.

    One arena is the development cost of public offices, which includes the buildings, fixtures and fittings to house the Government offices and the other is the operating and running costs. "The Seven Wonders of Singapore" were stated by Mr Tan Soo Khoon in this House before and we have to ask: can an efficient public service be delivered without spending millions of dollars on buildings, fixtures and fittings in the offices? Looking at our Government offices now, many are in first-class buildings, with extensive glass curtain walling, granites and marbles, with high-grade fixtures and fittings. They cost millions of dollars to build, and they have to spend just as much to maintain these dazzling glasses, marbles and granites. It is not to say that Government and its related agencies must always be housed in run-down looking buildings. By all means, progress and advance by having modern Government buildings, but this should not be extravagant.

    Last Thursday, while waiting for DPM Lee to arrive at Dhoby Ghaut station in

Column: 2941

the NEL train, I was marvelling at a five-storey high glass atrium and was wondering if the atrium had been lowered, would it help lower the charges of the NEL fare? We can have brilliantly sculptured stations, but if they cause transport cost to go up, it would leave commuters with a painful souvenir. Remember also there is a high depreciation cost for all this infrastructure which has to be paid annually.

    The important thing to remember is practicability. Does it make sense? Look at the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau. It is doing an effective public service but it is humbly housed in a recycled school building in Cantonment Road.

    Can these development costs be made more transparent for the public? I was searching through the HDB's annual reports for the current construction cost of HDB flats to ascertain a feedback given to me that the construction cost of a HDB flat has risen from about $40,000 in the 1990s to about $80,000 now. But I could not ascertain the cost from the annual reports. These are cost figures that the Cut Waste Panel should regularly monitor. HDB should also go back to the drawing board and ask what is its basic function. If its role is to provide good, quality public housing, then do so. Do not try to compete with the public sector and incorporate luxury into public housing. We have just recently debated in this House and spent time asking why the tempered glass shower screen cracks but we still have no answer. We cannot beat the private sector, because the prices are different and it is also for a different target market. Worse, we give luxury that is not luxurious, and the new flat owners hack out what we give and replace them. It is a waste of public funds. It only raises the cost of housing.

    Each Government department must look into how it has to manage its budget by cutting wastage, job enlargement or simplifying procedures.
